_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Matadero Tank and Chlorination Station is located at the State Road # 636, Km 0.1 Bo. Tanama Sector La Planta Arecibo, Puerto Rico, 00612.  This pump station is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.  PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program # 3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection: Chlorine.  The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part 68.  The Prevention Program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.



Accidental Release:

It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and State applicable requirements. Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason the Matadero Tank and Chlorination Station is already observing many engineering controls.  Changes have been put in place to improve security and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled.

Matadero Tank and Chlorination Station is located close to the area where the plants supply the potable water.  The chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans.



The chlorine is delivered from the San Juan Chlorine Warehouse and Distribution Center to the plant in one (1) ton containers, and cylinders of 150 pounds. Vacuum regulators are connected to ton containers. The chlorine gas passes from the vacuum regulators to the flexible connections, the chlorinators and the ejectors where the mixture of chlorine gas and water finally occurs. Also, at the facility there is a Chlorine Distribution Center. The 150 pounds cylinders stored at the facility are distributed to facilities in the Arecibo area. 



Worst Case Scenario:

Matade

ro Tank and Chlorination Station consists of two processes: chlorine injection (ton containers) and chlorine cylinders storage (150 pound) for eventual distribution to other PRASA facilities nearby. Due to both processes are close to each other, the worst case scenario for this facility was designed considering the widest extension of dispersion of the two process, which is the chlorine injection process.



The Worst Case Scenario was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2,000 pounds) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the weather conditions and a radio of 1.3 miles, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected. Environmental receptors (river and wetland)are located within this radio area.  



Alternative Case Scenario:

The alternative release scenario is more realistic scenario and was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters.  Matadero Tank and Chlorination Station consists of two processes: chlorine injection (ton containers) and chlorine cylinders storage (150 pound) for eventual distribution to other PRASA facilities nearby. Due to both processes are close to each other, the alternative release scenario for this facility was designed considering the widest extension of dispersion of the two process, which is the chlorine injection process. The alternative release scenario is a gas release of the entire contents of a ton container through a valve seal rupture.  The end point distance is calculated at 0.2 miles and 15 public receptors were identified over the most recent map.  Environmental receptors (river) are located within the radio area.



General Accident Release Prevention

Program 

PRASA is actually in a very aggressive operation to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facility which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans.  Standard Operational Procedures (SOP) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the chlorine.  List of all SOP are indicated in the PSM report and are located in the plant.



Emergency Response Program:

PRASA has various SOP to manage emergency programs associated to a release of the chemical and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events.



Five years Accident History:

No mayor release of chlorine in excess of ten (10) pounds has been reported during the last five years. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

PRASA has implemented in this facility, a vacuum system to improve process control and chlorine handling and storage safety.  



Audit:

Last compliance audit was conducted on June 26,2015.
